The curve in the road may be a pretty proper picture...
Yes, you may be in a sports car by yourself (and a younger and/or wilder kind of driver) or you may be the school bus driver - or, for that matter, just one of the inhabitants.
With that, your view of things will be radically different: exhilarated, exasperated, or just frightened.

What's best, though? Not one approach fits all, but a (certain) feeling of control will be called for, whether it's by competence as a decent driver, cautiously defensive driving, or trust in your driver - or, actually, by gripping the edge of your seat and closing your eyes shut.

Everybody will be doing something, and no one thing wil be best for everyone. If we want to have all get through the curve in one piece, we need to give everyone what they need, though: Not a consensus for how everyone has to handle things, but only a consensus that everyone who wants to, should have a chance (or more than a chance) to get through the curve, and the skills (or the drivers) to get them through.

And with that, let's all go to the next mirror and see: are we drivers, are we teachers, or are we just shouting at those who want to keep their eyes closed that they should open them and take the wheel, but not doing so ourselves?

Mark of Dallas asks: "What makes you think we have anything close to a workable solution to the problem of AGW today?

I think it is proven that what solutions have been tried, wont work."

We have the components of a solution — not only various forms of clean energy (including nuclear) which are being deployed and could be deployed faster, given more funding for R&D and the political will to speed up the permitting process. (Yes, I know nuclear is more expensive and more problematical. Too bad Clinton shut down the IFR program...)

We also have promising ideas for pulling CO2 out of the atmosphere, from planting more trees to chemical extraction, that need to be proven economically scalable.

The problem is not just scientific or technological; it is political. Specifically, status-quo energy companies do little to advance alternative energies and much to retard their deployment, while spending millions on blocking regulations that would better balance their own subsidized industries by putting a cost on carbon emissions. A great many citizens, misinformed by a cadre of professional obfuscators, willingly cooperate in delaying the necessary measures.

Environmental Mediation as an everyday responsibility is more and more welcome, but it is also conveniently overlooked as everyday matters continue on.
Large scale attempts to mediate climate change as regards mans activities, in terms of burning fossil fuels, have failed, and so have many other matters like fishing and forestation. As a result it could be that we all are in danger of tipping points and greater systems collapse.
This is a harsh way of looking at things since there have also been successes in mediating certain matters where the results have removed harmful elements from the ecosystem. And there is a real and substantive effort to replace at least a percentage of fossil fuel use with less potentially caustic methods. I realize there are those who feel that fossil fuel use is not at all caustic, coal and gases and etc.
However it could be that we are threatened: Straighten up and fly right or else. And perhaps it is true that this divine threat is on the verge of manifesting itself against us all. Whether we could even respond in time, too much mediation having already failed to find acceptance of reasonable possibilities, and having naively plundered on, is a really tragic question.
Mediation is sometimes a pre-court attempt to find an acceptable resolution. But we are also faced with courts that do not necessarily rule in favor of what we might think of as environmentally favorable.
I've seen TV stories about Brazil where murderers of environmentally concerned people go free after short jail terms and the amount of these murders are in the hundreds, and more then a thousand, and not just Chico Mendez and the Lady Sister Nun.
I am still curious about a dominant decider, a Meta Physician, someone who we might think was appointed by a Messiah to be listened to.
As simple as that might sound or seem to be, from the guy who throws his beer can out the window of his car, to the funky factory in China with the totally polluting coal electric generator, to the nation of Brazil and all the logging, to the UN and all it's weaknesses and disagreements and egos and power plays, we are all in a potentially dangerous situation due to environmental malfeasance.

The FCC can apply fines and other sanctions to public broadcasters if someone should utter a dirty word on the air. I read this editorial article written by a Canadian who has lived in China for a few years. In this article he compares the US-style two-party democracy where one party tries its best (including spreading blatant lies, not to mention mis-information and half-truths) to belittle and dis-credit the other party vs. the (idealized -- in my opinion) "one-party" democracy (or in fact, no-party meritocracy). It's an easy reading, as the article clearly illustrates the serious drawbacks and flaws of the current US political system at the Internet age, where lies travel faster than ever, especially among un-thinking masses.

The problem isn't just with FOX News blaring blatant propaganda like Michelle Bachmann's lies about the cost of the president's trip. It's that all media report that she says this nonsense without having the actual facts to counter the lie.

The media has fallen into the trap that the right has set up: that there are two equally valid sides to every argument. The prime example is the Big Lie that climate change isn't happening: news media still let climate change deniers spout their nonsense on the airwaves. All the science and our personal experience shows that it's happening right now. For example, in Minnesota we can now regularly play beach volleyball outdoors from March until November, and a scant ten or fifteen years that was just not possible because of all the snow on the ground.

If one side is blatantly lying the media are not obligated to let the liars spew their propaganda unchallenged. By repeating Bachmann's lies (and they are legion, according to PolitiFact) without also providing the actual facts, the media are complicit in the lie.

Mr. Friedman makes a partisan political argument that only the right engages in errors of facts. In fact they are widespread on both the right and left as is evident by examination of the numerous false claims by ideological partisans on both sides of the political spectrum. Even worse is the appalling decline in fact checking by journalists and editors. In the case of New York Times, Mr. Friedman conveniently forgets Jayson Blair, who wrote over 600 articles for the NYT's many of which were shown to contain fabrications, errors and overt plagiarism. Remember the CBS scandal with the fake documents concerning Mr. Bush’s National Guard Service revealed just before an election by Dan Rather. This is a list that could go on forever and would include Pulitzer Prize Winners who were caught fabricating stories. Until journalism cleans it own house we can hardily expect the political partisans to worry about facts.
